posts.author: n3xu5
posts.content:
I picked up the NWN1 EE for the PS4 and am trying to play thru the original campaign first, then HOU/SOTU.

The build I'm trying to follow picked fighter (1), and then bard (2)... problem is bard cannot be chosen on level 2.

1. Can anyone please explain why and if there's a reference guide I can read up on regarding class progression/caps/restrictions?
2.  Can I carry over my character from the OC to HOU/SOTU and what would the level caps be? 

Thanks in advance!

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hello N3xu5, and welcome to the Guild!

First off I'd better confess that I don't play EE or on PS4, so things may be different there - others will know better.

However, in ordinary, vanilla rules, there should be no problem with taking Fighter at level 1 and Bard at level 2 provided you haven't picked a lawful-aligned character (Bards can't be lawful). If you took them the other way around, that would be ok, but you'd need to start with a Charisma of 11. You'd gain skill points, but lose on stat points (unless you intend to be particularly charismatic, of course).

As far as carrying characters over from the OC to the expansions (which I initially did), you can, but it isn't advisable. SoU is designed to start with a level 1 character, much as the OC is, and you finish the OC at about level 17/18. You'd finish SoU at about level 13/14, so to play one after the other will make you massively overpowered. You can go from the OC straight to HotU (which ends at around level 28), but it's designed to be a follow-up to SoU.

If you want to take your character up to level 40, I'm afraid you'll have to download some modules or get into a Persistent World (where you can play with others). For modules, I'd suggest the OC and then into the Mines of Twin Summits trilogy, or SoU/ HotU then Sands of Fate - and we can give you details of them another time if you're interested.

Hope this helps a bit.

Cheers

EDIT: Sorry, nearly forgot, the NwN wiki will help with some knowledge of what works and what doesn't, but, particularly if you're playing a Bard, I'd also recommend having a read of Mick Dagger's guide to the class in our Game Guides forum. In fact, what sort of overall build are you looking for?
